body.p: To his Excelency the Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky. --

Your petitioner J H. Cayce will state that at the Decr Term of the Fulton Circuit Court ^from 1861^ he was fined the sum of sixty dollars upon a charge for keeping a Tipling house, in Fulton County, He states that prior to the finding of the indictment against him he obtained a License from the County Court of Fulton County Ky to keep a Tavern at Caye's Station in said County which tavern he kept & his Grocery or bar room he kept in a house a short distance from his Tavern house, believing at the time that it was no violation of law but for this he was evicted, & find,

He states that it seemed to be the impression of some attornies with whom he advised & they so instructed him that it was no violation of law & in fact the Commonwlth attorney who was then acting gave him the same opinion -- And when he was indicted he went to Hickman to make his defence & the attorney who was then acting Col Corbit advised him not to make any defense, as judgment would have to go against him in any way & that the facts presented to the Governor he had no doubt the fine would be remitted, He states that he some time since prepair & sent on a petition, together with the letter of Col Corbit, but has as yet received no answser -- Wherefore he asks for remission of said fine,

We whose names are hereto annexed respectfully request the Governor to remit the fine of Mr Cayce, we have no doubt he acted in Good faith & did not intend to violate the law. He is a man of limited means, Has a large family & recently he & his wife were seriously wounded in Columbus Ky, at their tavern by a deranged man, from which he has not yet recovered & probably will never entirely recover,

W, R, Bradley
E. B. Lovelace
H, C, Brown
J T Brown
J, M, Sanders
Taylor Bard
A. J. Cravett
N A Brevard
F. J. Coffee
Jno. T. Trent Co Co Clk

Hickman Ky
June the 11th 1863
Gov Robinson Dr Sir

I have Examined the within petition & I have no doubt but the Facts contained in it is all true I am well acquainted with Mr Cayce & his circumstances he is A poor man & Recently has met with A misfation of being stabbed & cripled for Life at the hands of A Lunatic & no doubt Justice will be done by you in Remision of the fine

Yours truly
W Herrin Shff of Fulton County
Samuel Landrum Judge of Fulton Quarterly & County Court

Fulton Cir. Ct
$60. } Tipling
Fine remitted except costs --
J F Robinson
J. H. Cayce
Issd July 24th 1863.
